td.strong: Four New COVID-19 Cases Traced to One Person
td.br:
(April 19, 2020) County Public Health Officials announced today two more COVID-19 cases with known contact to a co-worker who tested positive last week. Two other cases announced yesterday are also from known contact with the same individual. Read On...
Two New COVID-19 Cases Confirmed
(April 18th, 2020) Public health learned today of two new county residents who tested positive for COVID-19. Both had known contact with another person who tested positive. A 21-year-old male is the county’s 14th COVID-19 case and a 10-year-old female is the county’s 15th COVID-19 case.

div.class: inner col col24 first last idb6df7a11-cc19-496d-b573-c3c8d7aee824

ul.li:
2,583 tests have been processed
17 were positive
43 were borderline
2,523 were negative
A positive result on the first blood test means that an individual has been exposed to COVID-19 (and may or may not have ever experienced symptoms).

A borderline result on the first test indicates that the result produced a “high-signal flash” which is not enough to produce a positive result. It means that the individual may have been recently exposed to COVID-19 and/or may be in the early stage of producing antibodies.

A negative result on the first blood test means that an individual either has not been exposed to COVID-19 –OR— the person is in the window of having recently been exposed and has not yet developed antibodies that would make the test result be positive.

div.class: inner col col24 first last ida0ec04fe-4d30-4774-bdbe-d7219aac458c

div.h3: COUNTY PUBLIC HEALTH ORDER CURRENTLY IN EFFECT

div.class: inner col col24 first last idc7d17316-5674-4f0b-a5ff-d5c2d8c4f2b5

h3.a: County Public Health Order and Testing FAQs

li.a: Who can I reach out to for mental health concerns?
Which Public Health order are we following, the State’s that goes through April 26 or the County’s through May 1st?
Who do I contact with non-medical questions?
How long is the shelter in place order for?
Are the roads and public transit being shut down?

div.h3: State of Colorado Stay at Home Order
div.p: Governor Polis has issued a “Stay at Home” order for all Coloradans effective through April 26th, 2020. Read the state Public Health Order 20-24 and view the Frequently Asked Questions. San Miguel County is also under a similar order through May 1st.

ul.li: Public Health Order 20-04 (PDF) (In effect as of April 4, 2020)

a.aria-label: Local Disaster Emergency Declaration Extension April 2, 2020 (PDF) Opens in new window

li.a: Local Disaster Emergency Declaration Extension April 2, 2020 (PDF)

a.aria-label: Local Disaster Emergency Declaration March 16, 2020 (PDF) Opens in new window

div.h3: San Miguel County Essential Project Exemption Form
div.p: The purpose of this form is to provide San Miguel County staff with information needed to make a determination if you qualify for an exemption to the current Public Health Orders. Please download and complete this form and return it to planning@sanmiguelcountyco.gov.
div.h3: What does the Public Health Order in effect mean for me?

ul.li:
Please shelter in place!
Stay at home, leave only for essential errands (food and medications) and solo outdoor activity with no social contact
Prohibition of all events greater than 10 people
Prohibition of all events at daycare centers, childcare centers, home childcare centers, private schools and day schools, community recreational centers, ice rinks, and libraries
Cease operations and reservations for short-term lodging
Prohibition of all events at food establishments except for the provision of takeout and delivery of food
Cease all activities at all business facilities in the county except for minimum operations and essential services
Visitors to San Miguel County are directed to return home immediately. All non-resident homeowners are strongly encouraged to leave the county and return to their primary place of residence

div.p: For answers to specific questions, please see the Frequently Asked Questions tab.

Second-round testing has been delayed. However, San Miguel County and UBI are still committed to processing tests and initiating the second round of tests. Details will be released as they become available.

It may take the lab several days to process the blood samples. Once the results are received from the lab, County Public Health officials will immediately notify individuals by phone with positive results and explain recommended actions, including a possible PCR swab test to test for active disease.

Those who test negative on the first blood test will be notified by email, pending legal approval of the method as HIPPAA regulations have slightly loosened because of the COVID-19 pandemic. Those individuals who did not supply or do not have an email account will be notified by letter to the mailing address they provided upon registering.
Phone calls to individuals who test negative will only be done if no other method of contact can be accomplished. Read the March 31st press release for more details.
These posters are available for public use - please download, print, and display in your place of business.

div.p: For more information including workplace, school, and travel guidance, please visit the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) or the World Health Organization (WHO).
